turns.content: You are a therapist with many years of counselling survivors of childhood emotional trauma. Your specialty is working with clients who grew up in families dominated by emotionally immature parents. List a maladaptive belief that is irrational, negative and harmful relating to the subject of loving oneself. For that belief, provide an example of a 64-year-old male raised by a narcissistic mother who subscribed to the classical conditioning of good versus bad childhood behaviour. Limit maladaptive beliefs to the category of belief about self. Provide journal prompts that evaluate the validity of the belief, and write a 250-word journal entry to answer the prompt. Provide an alternative adaptive belief and list the benefits of adopting a more constructive, positive and rational belief that fosters a greater appreciation for and love of oneself. For each belief, self-protective behaviours that are unhelpful and adaptive behaviours that will help realize the benefits of the adaptive belief are included. Finish the answer with a declarative statement affirming the truth of the new belief and behaviour. Then summarize the answer in a prayer that follows this format. "Father. I repent of the belief that [insert the maladaptive belief]. Thank you for helping me reflect on [insert journal entry], and so I now choose to stop protecting myself by [insert the self-protection behaviour]. I receive a new belief [insert adaptive belief] and a new practice [insert adaptive behaviour] that will help me realize [insert benefits] and affirms my new identity as [insert declarative statement].

Maladaptive Belief: "I am unlovable and unworthy of love because I was never good enough for my mother."

Example: A 64-year-old male, raised by a narcissistic mother, was constantly criticized and made to feel like he could never meet her expectations. As a result, he grew up internalizing the belief that he is unlovable and unworthy of love.

Journal Prompts:

1. What evidence do I have that supports the belief that I am unlovable and unworthy of love?
2. How have my past experiences with my mother shaped my perception of my worthiness of love?
3. Are there other relationships or experiences that contradict this belief?

Journal Entry:
As I reflect on my childhood, I realize my narcissistic mother always expected perfection from me, and when I failed to meet her expectations, she was harsh and critical. I have spent years believing that I am unlovable and unworthy of love because I wasn't good enough for her. However, upon deeper reflection, I can identify instances where friends, partners, and even my own children have shown me love and appreciation. These relationships suggest that the belief of being unlovable may be rooted in my mother's behavior rather than my own inherent worth.

Alternative Adaptive Belief: "I am deserving of love and capable of giving love, regardless of my mother's expectations."

Benefits: Increased self-esteem, healthier relationships, greater self-compassion, and improved overall

well-being.

Unhelpful Self-Protective Behavior: Avoiding close relationships out of fear of rejection or not being good enough.

Adaptive Behavior: Actively seeking and cultivating deep, meaningful relationships while recognizing and asserting personal boundaries.

Declarative Statement: I am deserving of love and capable of giving love, regardless of my past experiences with my narcissistic mother.

Prayer:
"Father, I repent of the belief that I am unlovable and unworthy of love because I was never good enough for my mother. Thank you for helping me reflect on my relationships and experiences that contradict this belief. I now choose to stop protecting myself by avoiding close relationships out of fear. I receive a new belief that I am deserving of love and capable of giving love, regardless of my mother's expectations. I will practice actively seeking and cultivating deep, meaningful relationships while recognizing and asserting personal boundaries. This new belief and practice will help me realize increased self-esteem, healthier relationships, greater self-compassion, and improved overall well-being, affirming my new identity as a person deserving of love and capable of giving love. Amen."
